Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: We covered past tense for verbs and a variety of other vocabulary and grammar concepts. It was a good continuation of what we learned last semester because there was a combination of new and old concepts.
I learned to speak in the past tense and my vocabulary has increased exponentially!

This semester was primarily focused on learning the past tense verbs of Hebrew, but I also gained a lot of knowledge about Israeli culture. My speaking, reading, and especially writing skills were quite expanded this semester.
I improved my Hebrew vocabulary and learned past tense.

Strengths: Homework is very clear and organized. Feedback is prompt and helpful. All of the faculty (TA, professor, other speakers) were very kind and encouraging.
Weaknesses: I can't think of any!
Amazing professor! Quizzes and homework are very helpful!

Strength: contact time
Weakness: too often

Strengths: lots of cool, hands-on activities to learn Hebrew, which makes it a lot more fun. This class is super interactive, which is the best way to learn Hebrew. Orit is the sweetest lady and a great teacher. You get to listen to a lot of Israeli music and learn tons about the culture! Weaknesses: a lot of everyday work, which can be tedious, but is really the only way to learn as much as we've learned in one single semester.
The course is well organized. The workload is not overbearing. Content is engaging.
Yes! Hebrew is so fun to learn at Yale because the professors are engaging and the students become very close. It is very clear what is expected of the students and easy to improve.
Absolutely!! Such an amazing course!! I learned so much!! I feel like Im a great Hebrew speaker now!
Yes - if they want to learn Hebrew.

Absolutely. The Hebrew department at Yale is amazing and it's a great way to learn a really cool language and learn about the culture, too. The class is smaller than other language classes, which is really helpful for learning and makes the entire experience very personal.
Yes! It is a terrific continuation of learning Hebrew from L1.
